image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Warsaw, Wyoming County, N.Y., November 2, 1922; attended the Warsaw public schools; graduated from Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y., 1942; graduated from Cornell Law School, Ithaca, N.Y., 1948; United States Marine Corps; United States Marine Corps Reserve; lawyer, private practice; member of the New York state senate, 1963-1964; elected as a Republican to the Eighty-ninth and to the nine succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1965-January 3, 1985); not a candidate for reelection to the Ninety-ninth Congress in 1984; World Bank executive,1986-1991; died on November 30, 2003, in Sarasota, Fla.; interment in Alexander Cemetery, Alexander, N.Y.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Conable, Barber B., Jr. The Conable Years at the World Bank: Major Policy Addresses of Barber B. Conable, 1986-91. Washington, D.C.: World Bank, 1991.

Conable, Barber B., Jr., and John Charles, Moderator, et al. Controlling the Cost of Social Security: Held on June 25, 1981 and Sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research. Washington, D.C.: The Institute, 1981.
Conable, Barber B., Jr., Richard S. Belous, S. Dahlia Stein, Nita Christine Kent, eds. Foreign Assistance in a Time of Constraints. Washington, D.C.: National Planning Association, 1995.
Conable, Barber B., Jr., with A.L. Singleton. Congress and The Income Tax. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1989.
Fleming, James S. Window on Congress: A Congressional Biography of Barber B. Conable, Jr. Rochester, N.Y: University of Rochester Press, 2004.
Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: Barber B. Conable, Jr., Republican Representative from New York. Washington, D.C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

researchRecord.name: 1960-1985, 605.1 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Barber Conable, which were generated during his tenure as a New York State Senator and United States Congressman. Also included is a narrative account of his experiences with the World Bank. All files, except case files, are closed for ten years from the creation of the file except with written permission of the donor. Case files are closed for thirty years from the initiation of the file except by written permission of the donor.

researchRecord.name: In the William Syers Research Interviews, 1984-1985, approximately 1 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Topics of the interviews concerns Gerald R. Ford's congressional career and his approach to congressional relations as president. Persons interviewed include Barber Conable. A finding aid is available in the repository.
